1.question: What conclusion can be drawn if a mosaic plot shows empty cell combinations at high levels?

options.A: Interaction does not exist in the dataset
options.D: The dimensionality leads to sparse category intersections

2.question: What insight is gained from aligning axes at the median in parallel coordinate plots?

options.A: Enhanced comparison of differences between observations

3.question: Which characteristic distinguishes trellis displays from other high-dimensional plots in terms of model diagnostics?

options.A: Use of unique axis scaling per panel
options.B: Common scale across panels for accurate comparison
options.C: Ability to render more than seven variables

4.question: Which of the following BEST justifies the positioning of variables in a mosaic plot for analyzing interaction effects?

options.A: Place variables with the most categories at the end
options.B: Position conditioning variables first, followed by interaction variables
options.D: Randomize the order to ensure objectivity

5.question: How do interactive trellis displays support exploratory data analysis?

options.C: By removing continuous variables from view
options.D: By plotting expected values instead of observed ones

6.question: Which visualization method would be least effective without interactivity?

7.question: Why might parallel coordinate plots be limited when applied to datasets with hundreds of observations?

options.B: Too many color categories make it unreadable
options.D: The plot suffers from overplotting and visual clutter

8.question: In evaluating visualizations of high-dimensional data, why might linked highlighting be crucial?

options.D: It maintains the multivariate context across multiple plots

options.A: Their ability to scale gene clusters in 3D
options.B: Their use of color gradients to represent multivariate expression levels
options.D: Their reliance on bar chart overlays

11.question: What key characteristic distinguishes thematic maps from topographic maps?

options.C: They provide accurate earth surface features

options.D: To reflect hierarchy among data across categories

options.C: They increase the file size of the map
options.D: They make maps colorful and attractive

options.A: It allows dynamic exploration of patterns
options.C: It replaces traditional maps completely for a better outlook

16.question: When mapping change over time, which method provides the most dynamic visualization?

options.A: They are unable to emphasize the most important category
options.D: They may distort perception by implying importance

options.A: Always uses black and white visuals for effective visualization
options.D: Represents distribution of a specific theme

22.question: What best indicates that a visualization has misrepresented the data?

options.C: It leads to incorrect conclusions among viewers

options.A: By determining if the visualizations support a logical narrative
options.C: By counting the number of slides or visuals used

options.B: The font style of the title
options.C: The match between data types and visualization forms

25.question: How can cognitive load be reduced in data visualizations?

options.A: Combine all data into one chart

26.question: What is the most effective way to evaluate whether a data visualization communicates the intended message?

options.A: Ensure the chart uses vibrant colors
options.B: Test the visualization with real users for comprehension
options.C: Count the number of chart types used
options.D: Check if the data source is cited

27.question: Why is evaluating sociocultural context important in visualization?

options.C: It ensures diverse interpretation is considered

28.question: What are examples of open-ended evaluation techniques for visualizations?

options.C: Ask users what trend they observed

29.question: Which aspect is most important in evaluating a dashboard designed for decision-making?

options.D: It highlights key performance indicators clearly
